central_thesis: The Tarot, particularly Key 7 (The Chariot), represents the operation of Will-power driven by self-consciousness, which acts as a charioteer guiding the vehicle of personality (the body) by means of the intellect and mind, with the senses as horses. This process is deeply rooted in Pythagorean and Kabbalistic principles, linking the physical universe, human consciousness, and divine influence through symbolic representation and practical application.

structure_content.summary: This lesson introduces Key 7, The Chariot, linking it to the Pythagorean concept of 'vehiculum' and its Indian origins. It explains the symbolism of the charioteer (intellect), the horses (senses), and the reins (mind) guiding the Self through life's experiences. The text emphasizes the role of self-consciousness and discriminative power, symbolized by the city in the background, and connects it to the sublimation of reproductive forces through libido. The chariot's elements (stone fence, windbreak, river, chariot itself, rider in armor) are analyzed as repeated references to the Hebrew letter Cheth (ח), signifying 'wall' or 'enclosure'. The lesson delves into the Kabbalistic connections of the chariot's cubic form to the Cube of Space and the concept of 'Ab' (Father) and Wisdom. It also explores the cycles of energy represented by the chariot's wheels and their link to Key 10 and Jupiter. The directional correspondences within the Cube of Space are detailed, showing how Key 7 (East Below) relates to the subconscious operations of the Emperor and Hierophant, contrasting with Key 6 (East Above) which links reason and intuition at a self-conscious level. Key 7 is presented as primarily dealing with Life-power at subconscious levels, involving creative imagination and memory, related to the sign Cancer, nutrition, and digestion, with subconsciousness as the ruling power.

This section elaborates on the Chariot's symbolism, connecting its cube shape to the High Priestess's cubic stone and the noun 'eben' (stone). It discusses the Kabbalistic association of 'Ab' with Wisdom, zodiacal forces, and life-force derived from celestial bodies. The cycles of transformation of this energy are linked to the chariot's wheels and Key 10. The direction East-Below (Cheth) is assigned to the chariot, connecting it to the lower ends of the Emperor's (North-East) and Hierophant's (South-East) lines in the Cube of Space, contrasting with the Lovers' East-Above line. Key 7 is presented as synthesizing the first row of Keys (1-7), representing the externalization of mental images (Key 3) through reason (Key 4), intuition testing (Key 5), and discrimination between self and superconsciousness (Key 6), culminating in the creation of physical vehicles and the awareness of the One Self as the true rider. The sphinxes are interpreted as representing the senses and pairs of opposites, which the Self, guided by intellect, learns to control for security and peace. The concept of the inner Self being above and beyond personality, with personality as a mere vehicle for the One Will and Astral Light, is introduced.

This part continues the philosophical exploration of Key 7. The chariot is seen as the vehicle of personality, its materials flowing from the cosmic environment and cosmic forces flowing out of it. The four pillars supporting the canopy symbolize the four elements and the Hermetic axiom 'As above, so below', with the central ring representing Spirit. The starry canopy symbolizes celestial forces and 'Astral Light'. The shield on the chariot depicts the lingam-yoni, symbolizing the union of opposites. The winged globe above it represents solar power and atmospheric moisture. The charioteer's crown with three pentagrams signifies dominion over three planes via speech. The green wreath links to the Fool, and the armor to the Emperor. Crescents on the shoulders represent Mercury and Severity, with corresponding smiling and frowning faces. The cuirass, green-yellow like brass (Venus), signifies protection and order. The skirt and belt bear geomantic symbols and the zodiac, with specific references to Cancer and the moon. The charioteer's scepter combines symbols of the Magician and High Priestess, signifying mastery over both self-consciousness and subconsciousness. Key 7 is declared the synthesis of the first row of Keys, showing how acts of attention (Key 1) lead to subconscious associative functions (Key 2), creating external conditions (Key 3) through reason (Key 4), tested intuition (Key 5), and discrimination (Key 6), resulting in the awareness of the True Self as the rider of personality. The section emphasizes that 'All Power Is Yours,' and Key 7 answers fundamental questions about identity, positioning us beyond mere physical bodies to a universal consciousness. It defines the 'stuff' of bodies as 'Astral Light' and the Chariot's river as its flowing representation. The practice involves cultivating the inner Self's awareness above personality and using 'Astral Light' as the medium for influence. A practical exercise is recommended: deep stillness and imagination to realize personality as a vehicle for flowing influences, sending out blessings in six directions.

key_concepts.definition: Represents the Will-power that directs the vehicle of personality, guided by intellect and mind. It symbolizes the conscious direction of life's journey, the synthesis of self-consciousness and subconsciousness, and the control of the senses and dualities.
The true rider of the chariot, the essential being or consciousness that is above and beyond personality. It is the source of Will and the guiding principle of the vehicle.
The discriminative faculty that guides the chariot and controls the powerful senses (horses).
The controlling mechanism that allows the intellect to direct the senses and the vehicle.
The powerful, often restive, forces that propel the vehicle but must be guided by the intellect and mind.
The 'vehicle' or 'chariot' that the Self uses to navigate life. It is a shaping of the fundamental 'stuff' of the universe (Astral Light).

The fundamental substance or energy of the universe, described as a flowing, ever-moving fluidic 'stuff', which forms all bodies and vehicles. It is the medium through which influences flow and is associated with cosmic forces.
A symbolic representation of the physical universe and human personality, where directions, elements, and Tarot Keys are mapped. The chariot's cubic shape signifies this connection.
The Hebrew letter associated with The Chariot, meaning 'wall' or 'enclosure.' It appears symbolically in the imagery of the lesson (fence, wall, river, armor) as repetitions of this concept.
The subconscious force, as understood in analytical psychology, which can be lifted up or sublimated through the constructive function of self-consciousness, related to Will-power.

practical_system.description: The system described is based on understanding and consciously directing the forces of consciousness and subconsciousness through the symbolism of Tarot, particularly Key 7. It involves recognizing the 'Self' as the true agent, personality as the vehicle, and the intellect and mind as the guiding faculties. The ultimate goal is self-mastery and alignment with a universal consciousness, achieved through the understanding and application of esoteric principles like the Cube of Space, Hebrew letters, and the concept of Astral Light. The practice involves developing discriminative awareness, controlling the senses, and integrating subconscious and conscious powers.
tools: Symbolic understanding of Kabbalah (Hebrew letters, Cube of Space)
rituals: A practical exercise involving deep stillness, imagination to perceive personality as a vehicle for flowing influences, and sending out blessings in six directions (up, down, east, west, north, south) to cultivate awareness of the inner Self and universal connection.

relevant_quotes.text: "The Self is the rider in the chariot of the body, guided by the intellect as charioteer, drawn by the senses as powerful horses, controlled by way of the mind serving for the reins. Thus runs the vehicle over the course of experience."
"He who has the intellect for his driver and the mind for proper reins, is able to reach the other end of the course, the highest essence of the All-pervading."

"The true development of Will-power, symbolized by Key 7, has behind it the constructive function of self-consciousness. Our exercise of this function brings about a lifting-up or sublimation of the reproductive forces of the physical body. This is accomplished by a release of the subconscious force analytical psychology calls libido."

The body of the chariot is a cube like that whereon sits the High Priestess. Review what is said of the cubic stone in Lessons 8 and 12. See also the explanation of the noun אבןeben, "stone", in Lesson 14.

"What is intimated here is that the mental activities represented by Key 6 link together reason and intuition (Emperor and Hierophant) at the level of self-conscious mental activity represented by the Magician. On the other hand, the functions represented by Key 7 unite the powers of the Emperor and the Hierophant at the level of subconscious activity represented by the High Priestess."
Key 7 refers primarily to operations of the Life-power occurring at subconscious levels. They are combinations of creative imagination (East; Empress) and memory (Below; High Priestess).

The cubical shape of the car, which is, remember, a symbol also of human personality, intimates the following idea: The true body of man is the physical universe. By no means is it merely the localized structure of flesh and blood and bones we use during a single incarnation.

By the invisible reins of the mind we let the Self guide the vehicle of personality. The result is that the motive-power of sensation is brought to rest, as are the sphinxes in this version, or the horses which draw the chariot in some older designs.

The symbols of a chemical formula are purely arbitrary. Those of a Tarot Key possess the added advantage that, being founded on laws of human mental activity--the same, yesterday, today and forever-the meaning of the symbols never can be wholly lost.
This is true because the symbols are part of the one universal human language-a language older than any human "tongue"---and this is the occult "speech" which is associated with Key 7.
To learn this language, we must learn to still our wagging tongues. To realize our actual omnipresence, we must stop identifying ourselves with our flesh-and-blood bodies.

If we persist in this, the time will come when we shall know that our one body is the whole universe, and that our One Self (pictured as the Charioteer) is no other than the Living Mind which eternally creates and sustains the universe.

critical_analysis.relevance: This work is highly relevant to students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in Tarot as a symbolic system for psychological and spiritual development. Case's synthesis of Pythagorean, Kabbalistic, and Hermetic principles provides a structured, intellectual framework for understanding the Tarot's deeper meanings and their application to personal transformation. It bridges theoretical understanding with practical implications for self-mastery.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Students of Tarot, Western Esotericism, Occultism, Hermeticism, and Kabbalah. Individuals seeking a deeper understanding of consciousness, symbolism, and personal empowerment through occult philosophy. Practitioners interested in a structured, intellectual approach to magical development and self-awareness.
